name: Early Network Security Policies
description: Understanding the foundational security policies that shaped modern network defenses.

cards.title: ARPANET and the Birth of Network Security (1969-1973)
cards.description: Early security challenges in ARPANET (Advanced Research Projects Agency Network), the first packet-switching network and predecessor to the modern internet.
bulletpoints: ARPANET was launched by the U.S. Department of Defense in 1969.
The first documented hacking incident occurred in 1972 when an unauthorized user accessed the system.
Early networks had weak security, relying on simple passwords.

cards.title: Introduction of Firewalls (1988-1993)
cards.description: Firewalls were developed as a security mechanism to filter traffic between trusted and untrusted networks.
bulletpoints: First-generation firewalls used simple packet filtering to block or allow traffic based on IP addresses and port numbers.
Stateful firewalls, introduced in the early 1990s, tracked the state of active connections.
Network perimeter security became a fundamental aspect of cybersecurity.

cards.title: The Evolution of Encryption Standards (1976-2001)
cards.description: The development of modern encryption standards, including Data Encryption Standard (DES), Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), and Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).
bulletpoints: DES was developed by IBM and adopted by the U.S. government in 1976.
AES replaced DES in 2001 due to increasing concerns over brute-force attacks.
SSL/TLS (Transport Layer Security) was introduced in 1995 to secure web communications.

cards.title: The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA) (1986)
cards.description: The U.S. government introduced CFAA to criminalize unauthorized access to computer systems.
bulletpoints: Passed in 1986 in response to early hacking incidents.
Made it illegal to access government and financial networks without authorization.
Expanded over the years to include cyber espionage and fraud.

cards.title: Introduction of Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) (1980s-1990s)
cards.description: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) were developed to monitor network traffic for suspicious activity.
bulletpoints: First IDS concepts introduced in the 1980s.
Network-based IDS (NIDS) and Host-based IDS (HIDS) became common in the 1990s.
IDS evolved into modern Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS).

cards.title: First Recorded Computer Worm: The Morris Worm (1988)
cards.description: The Morris Worm was the first self-replicating computer worm, causing 10% of internet-connected systems to fail.
bulletpoints: Created by Robert Tappan Morris, a Cornell University student.
Exploited vulnerabilities in Unix systems.
Led to the creation of the Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT).

cards.title: First Implementation of Public Key Cryptography (1976)
cards.description: Public Key Cryptography (PKC) revolutionized secure communication by allowing encrypted messages to be exchanged without a pre-shared key.
bulletpoints: Developed by Whitfield Diffie and Martin Hellman.
Enabled the use of asymmetric encryption, laying the foundation for modern digital security.
Later refined into RSA encryption by Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard Adleman in 1978.

cards.title: Development of the First Anti-Virus Software (1987)
cards.description: As malware threats emerged, security researchers developed the first antivirus solutions.
bulletpoints: First known antivirus tool: 'Vaccine' by Bernd Fix, developed in 1987.
McAfee and Norton launched commercial antivirus software in the late 1980s.
Signature-based detection became the standard for early antivirus programs.

cards.title: Introduction of Secure Email Standards: PGP (1991)
cards.description: Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) was introduced as a method to encrypt and authenticate email communications.
bulletpoints: Developed by Phil Zimmermann in 1991.
Used a combination of symmetric and asymmetric encryption.
Became the basis for modern email encryption standards.

cards.title: The Rise of Network Access Control (NAC) Policies (1990s)
cards.description: Network Access Control (NAC) was introduced to ensure that only authenticated and authorized users could access networks.
bulletpoints: Implemented in enterprise environments to enforce security policies.
Used authentication mechanisms like RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service) and TACACS+ (Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System).
Modern NAC solutions integrate with Zero Trust security models.
